bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to W.S. Leathers, March 23, 1923

div1.p: Carter informs Leathers about his career in malaria and yellow fever control and the careers of others prominent in the field.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to W.S. Leathers, March 23, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
March 23, 1923.
Dr. W. S. Leathers,
State Health Officer,
Mississippi State Board of Health,
Jackson, Miss.
Dear Doctor Leathers:
div1.p: Your letter of the 17th. received yesterday.

I am exceedingly busy so that, with the exception of this let-
ter, I am attending to my personal mail only on Sundays. I will be
unable then to give you any extensive data on the subjects of which
you inquire, but will do what I can.

1/ You should add Taliaferro Clarke, of the Public Health Service,
to the list of the men who have been prominent in sanitation. His
work both in trachoma and child hygiene has been extremely good.
You will shortly--unless I am no judge of men--have also to add the
name of L. L. Williams Jr.--working in malaria in Virginia--and pro-
bably H. McG. Robertson.

For Frost, in my judgment, he is the foremost epidemiologist that
we now have in America.

2) Much of my own work has been done abroad--in Panama: Peru and in in-
vestigationoof other parts of South America. In the United States, the
,the
-2-
control of malaria was begun by myself--Roanoke Rapids being the first
place attempted--and I had more or less to do with it from that time to
my going to Peru to substitute Gorgas in the spring of 1920. The work
here (Peru) was part of that planned by the Rockefeller Foundation in
1915 for the elimination of yellow fever from the globe, and resulting
(withthanks to Hanson's help) in complete--and I believe permanent--elimination
of the great focus of the West Coast of South America: the first step
we had planned in this work.

Frankly, I think that really the most important thing that I have
done for the control of malaria in the U. S. was in securing the ser-
vices of Mr. LePrince for it. Otherwise, I am quite sure, that he
would have been with the English in South Africa. I doubt if even you
know how valuable in this work he has been.

I am sending this Memorandum, herewith enclosed, because not one
man in ten--I except Welch: Rosenau: Reed etc.) seems to know exactly
(a) what the “extrinsic incubation of yellow fever was,” or (b) in
what way it affected Reed's work at Quemados. Both should be of spe-
cial interest to yourself as the culmination of the work was from Or-
wood and Taylor, Miss, whence I was able to present data, convincing to
the most skeptical, of the truth of the thesis of which I had been con-
vinced for some years.

I am also asking my daughter to send you such papers as are imme-
diately available, bearing on this subject. I have not access to my
old files.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Enclosure.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
